prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal Group 1 low
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Low LO1 setting for Group 1 LO1 = 101.175 GHz
Note: this SB is independent on configuration. Countinuum source is <<10uarcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This is a detection experiment. We have no knowledge of the actual width of the absorption lines. Based on previous experience the absorption lines can vary from ~1 km/s (in which case its strength will be diminished by our correlator setup), to ~50 km/s.
We have selected targets and the particular LO1 setting for each Scheduling Block in order to maximize the number of sources that have at least one of 14 target spectral lines in either the LSB or USB. Most target will actually have more than one line present, but as we target the redshift of the host galaxy of each AGN, even a single line will give a secure detection of molecular absorption.

The background sources are point sources for any ALMA configuration. The actual angular extent of the mm emission region is believed to be <<30uarcsec. Hence, our observation is configuration independent.

This is a detection experiment where we are searching for molecular absorption lines towards radio bright AGNs. The targets have a continuum flux of 100 mJy or larger. The integration time per source is set by our aim of detecting an absorption line of a strength of ~10% of the continuum flux with a width of 6 km/s towards the faintest of our targets. We used the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator with a channel-to-channel sensitivity limit of 3.5mJy and a line width of 6 km/s. This gives a 3sigma detection of an absorption line of depth ~10mJy. For sources with a stronger continuum, our sensitivity will be better and scales linearly with the continuum strength of the background source. Since the sources are variable, we cannot vary the integration time per source.
In order to cover a large redshift space, we propose to use the 1.875GHz spectral windows with a velocity resolution of ~3.5 km/s. This will be binned to a spectral resolution of 6 km/s during data analysis.

This is a non-standard observing mode. Each Scheduling Block consists of a single tuning with the regular calibration sequence. However, we have 20 targets spread out over +25<DEC<90 and a RA intervall of 4 hours. The idea is to observe each target for 4 minutes. Calibration and overhead accounts for ~20 minutes according to the ALMA OT. Total execution time for each SB is thus 100 minutes.
In the OT we have put a single source in each SB. The ALMA OT does not allow sources separated by more than 10d for a standard observing mode. Hence, we added the on-source time (with overheads) for and additional 19 sources. These 19 sources will be added during the phase 2 preparation.

We have set the spectral averaging to a factor 2, resulting in a data rate of 12.21 Mb/s. This is just above the target bitrate. While we can do further spectral averaging, we prefer to keep the spectral resolution as high as possible due to the potential for narrow absorption lines.

Our targets consist of continuum sources from the ALMA calibrator catalog. These can be successfully be used for self-calibration. We have therefore removed the dynamic phase calibrator and replaced it with the target itself. This will be repeated for the additional 19 sources that will be added to each scheduling Block in the Phse 2 process.

This is a detection experiment where we are searching for molecular absorption lines towards radio bright AGNs. The targets have a continuum flux of 100 mJy or larger. The integration time per source is set by our aim of detecting an absorption line of a strength of ~10% of the continuum flux with a width of 6 km/s towards the faintest of our targets. We used the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator with a channel-to-channel sensitivity limit of 3.5mJy and a line width of 6 km/s. This gives a 3sigma detection of an absorption line of depth ~10mJy. For sources with a stronger continuum, our sensitivity will be better and scales linearly with the continuum strength of the background source. Since the sources are variable, we cannot vary the integration time per source.
In order to cover a large redshift space, we propose to use the 1.875GHz spectral windows with a velocity resolution of ~3.5 km/s. This will be binned to a spectral resolution of 6 km/s during data analysis.

This is a non-standard observing mode. Each Scheduling Block consists of a single tuning with the regular calibration sequence. However, we have 20 targets spread out over +25<DEC<90 and a RA intervall of 4 hours. The idea is to observe each target for 4 minutes. Calibration and overhead accounts for ~20 minutes according to the ALMA OT. Total execution time for each SB is thus 100 minutes.
In the OT we have put a single source in each SB. The ALMA OT does not allow sources separated by more than 10d for a standard observing mode. Hence, we added the on-source time (with overheads) for and additional 19 sources. These 19 sources will be added during the phase 2 preparation.

We have set the spectral averaging to a factor 2, resulting in a data rate of 12.21 Mb/s. This is just above the target bitrate. While we can do further spectral averaging, we prefer to keep the spectral resolution as high as possible due to the potential for narrow absorption lines.

Our targets consist of continuum sources from the ALMA calibrator catalog. These can be successfully be used for self-calibration. We have therefore removed the dynamic phase calibrator and replaced it with the target itself. This will be repeated for the additional 19 sources that will be added to each scheduling Block in the Phse 2 process.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal Group 6 high
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
LO1 = 101.525 GHz
Note: This SB is configuration independent. The continuum source is <<10uarcsec.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This is a detection experiment. We have no knowledge of the actual width of the absorption lines. Based on previous experience the absorption lines can vary from ~1 km/s (in which case its strength will be diminished by our correlator setup), to ~50 km/s.
We have selected targets and the particular LO1 setting for each Scheduling Block in order to maximize the number of sources that have at least one of 14 target spectral lines in either the LSB or USB. Most target will actually have more than one line present, but as we target the redshift of the host galaxy of each AGN, even a single line will give a secure detection of molecular absorption.

The background sources are point sources for any ALMA configuration. The actual angular extent of the mm emission region is believed to be <<30uarcsec. Hence, our observation is configuration independent.

This is a detection experiment where we are searching for molecular absorption lines towards radio bright AGNs. The targets have a continuum flux of 100 mJy or larger. The integration time per source is set by our aim of detecting an absorption line of a strength of ~10% of the continuum flux with a width of 6 km/s towards the faintest of our targets. We used the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator with a channel-to-channel sensitivity limit of 3.5mJy and a line width of 6 km/s. This gives a 3sigma detection of an absorption line of depth ~10mJy. For sources with a stronger continuum, our sensitivity will be better and scales linearly with the continuum strength of the background source. Since the sources are variable, we cannot vary the integration time per source.
In order to cover a large redshift space, we propose to use the 1.875GHz spectral windows with a velocity resolution of ~3.5 km/s. This will be binned to a spectral resolution of 6 km/s during data analysis.

This is a non-standard observing mode. Each Scheduling Block consists of a single tuning with the regular calibration sequence. However, we have 20 targets spread out over +25<DEC<90 and a RA intervall of 4 hours. The idea is to observe each target for 4 minutes. Calibration and overhead accounts for ~20 minutes according to the ALMA OT. Total execution time for each SB is thus 100 minutes.
In the OT we have put a single source in each SB. The ALMA OT does not allow sources separated by more than 10d for a standard observing mode. Hence, we added the on-source time (with overheads) for and additional 19 sources. These 19 sources will be added during the phase 2 preparation.

We have set the spectral averaging to a factor 2, resulting in a data rate of 12.21 Mb/s. This is just above the target bitrate. While we can do further spectral averaging, we prefer to keep the spectral resolution as high as possible due to the potential for narrow absorption lines.

Our targets consist of continuum sources from the ALMA calibrator catalog. These can be successfully be used for self-calibration. We have therefore removed the dynamic phase calibrator and replaced it with the target itself. This will be repeated for the additional 19 sources that will be added to each scheduling Block in the Phse 2 process.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to search for molecular absorption lines towards 240 radio loud AGNs. The sources are selected from the ALMA calibrator catalog and have known redshifts. The high redshift absorbers found in this survey will be used to obtain detailed information about the physical and chemical conditions in the ISM of the AGN host galaxies as well as for studies of the invariance of fundamental constants and for measuring the temperature of the cosmic microwave background as a function of redshift. The execution of the observations requires a non-standard approach, but makes use of a tested and established observing procedure. This type of large scale survey for molecular absorption is only possible with a telescope as sensitive as ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Catholic University of America

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: National Centre for Radio Astrophysics, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research
Department of Astronomy, Maryland, University of
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
